texts.en: Mrs. Kuy S. is a villager in Prey Khvav village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and has a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Em Pheap, sells fish. Even though they have different businesses, they still do not earn enough money to afford good living conditions. Thus, Mrs. Kuy S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to transport her husband’s business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living with this loan. She is 24 years old and the mother of child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to provide transportation for her husband’s fish-selling business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn C. is a 45-year old mother of five who lives in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. She and her husband work hard to keep their children in school. Her husband is a farmer who manages a family-owned rice field. Marilyn knows that a better future for her children will not be possible if she depends solely on the income her husband makes while farming, so she has decided to go into business for herself as a hog farmer. 

She started her hog-raising project in her backyard in 2007, using a loan as start-up capital to purchase a sow. After four months, she was able to raise two hogs which she sold at a profit. She used that profit to buy additional piglets.

Marilyn has learned that she can generate more money from her business by raising more capital.  That's why she is applying for a loan to buy feed for her animals. During an interview, she said that, “I believe that quality feed can increase the yield of my hogs. If I can do that, I not only increase my income, but also help my husband sustain the needs of our children, especially their education.”

loans.use: To buy feed for her hobs

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
“I am thankful that God blessed me with responsible and obedient children.  I am willing to sacrifice everything for them,” Rosita shares.  

Rosita L., together with her husband, children and grandchildren, live happily in Sisim Alto Tumauini, Isabel. They have five children: Rodan – 30 years old and high school graduate; Reynante – 28 years old; Rubilyn Dignos – 26 years old, college graduate, a housewife; Randy – 23 years old, college graduate and now working in Pampanga; and the youngest is Reginard – 20 years old and currently an agriculture student. 

Rosita is a simple vegetable vendor in their village earning an average of PHP600.00 a week. Her husband is engaged in organic rice farming and also serves as a councilor in their village. With this type of business, the couple successfully send all their children to school.  She is hoping that their youngest will also graduate from college in the future.

“My plan is to have a vegetable booth in the public market where I can generate higher income to help my husband earn money to support our daily needs and farm maintenance,” Rosita said. With this in mind, she would like to request a loan to add capital to make her business plan a reality.

loans.use: To acquire a vegetable stall in the public market

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men T. is 28 years old and resides with her parents and her sister in Battanbang province, Cambodia. She is single and helps support her family by working as farmer and professional tailor. She grows rice and decorates clothes; on average, she makes US$ 5 a day. Of course, this family also gets support from Men Saream, 25, a sister of Men T., who works selling handbags at the market. She earns approximately US$ 6 a day.

Ms. Men T. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to make two investments. First, she will spend US$ 300 to purchase fertilizer and rice seeds for her farm. Second, she plans to invest with her sister to add to their handbag inventory to meet her customers’ demand.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and invest in the handbag business

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is the daughter of A. and lives in the first district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives together with her husband and two of her children who are students. Her husband has a metal shop. He is a hard-working man and tries to give his family a comfortable life and educate their children. Amina wants to take an individual loan of 42,000 Afghani for a term of 12 months. Through the loan, her husband wants to expand his business and to buy some essential tools which can make his work easier.

loans.use: Buying essential tools for her husband's shop

loans.name: Alionza

texts.es: Alioza tiene 42 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en la casa de su madre. Se dedica al bordado, arte que aprendió gracias a unas amigas, con el tiempo consiguió ser más creativa, y ahora esas amigas están muy contentas de haberle apoyado, pues vendía tamales en los mercados y necesitaba una actividad adicional para incrementar sus ingresos económicos y gracias a este arte recibe todos los días una muy buena cantidad de polos para ser bordados, actividad que realiza en su casa. Sin embargo, sigue dedicándose a la venta de tamales, pues recibe pedidos para diversas fiestas, donde elabora grandes cantidades de este platillo para servir a los invitados. La prioridad de Alioza es instalar un taller de bordados, pues es un negocio muy rentable debido a los pedidos de exportación que están aumentando y contar con  maquinaria adecuada la ayudaría mucho. Ella es cliente de MFP desde hace 4 años, este es su quinto préstamo, el cual le ayudó a relacionarse con las personas y conformar un bonito equipo de trabajo responsable. Aloiza invertirá 1200 soles en comprar materiales para incrementar la cantidad de sus bordados, y con ello aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Alionza is 42 years old and lives with her husband and children in her mother's house. She embroiders for a living, an art that she learned thanks to some friends. Over time she has become more creative with her embroidery, and now these friends are very happy to have helped her. She used to sells tamales in the markets, and needed an additional activity to increase her income. Thanks to this art, everyday she receives a good quantity of polo neck sweaters to be embroidered, an activity which she carries out at home. Nevertheless, she continues selling tamales, as she receives orders for different holidays when large quantities of this dish are served to guests. Alionza's priority is to install an embroidery workshop, as it is a very profitable business thanks to increasing export orders, and having adequate machinery would help her greatly. She has been a client of MFP for four years, and this is her fifth loan. MFP has helped her to build relationships with people and form part of good team that works responsibly. Alionza will use the 1,200 soles to buy materials to increase the quantity of her embroidery, and thus increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase embroidery material

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Lun S. is 30 years old and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She raises pigs and is able to make about US$5 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a recycler and earns US$4 per day. This couple has three children and all of them are in school. Lun S. is asking for a loan for her husband to reinvest in his recycling business.

loans.use: To reinvest in the recycling business.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia L., 22, is single with no children. She has 2 years of experience in the vegetable business. She sells to the general public four days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 104 Tala (approximately 35 USD).

Rosalia has no previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Rosalia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, a spade, a wheelbarrow, cabbage seeds, gloves, a weed cutter, a rake and a water hose

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: La Joven María Elena M. H. tiene la edad de 44 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña María tiene 2 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que es importante resaltar que su negocio inicio por la necesidad de no poseer un empleo, ya que tenia que alimentar a su familia. Y con los financiamientos ha podido salir adelante. Los propósitos de María Elena son de tener los recursos necesarios para la inversión de su negocio. María decide realizar un financiamiento con Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas que ayudan con esta causa y comprar productos como golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan y jugos. Los sueños de María es de ofertar un mejor servicio a sus clientes para que le permita mejorar y aumentar clientes.
texts.en:
Maria Elena M. H. is 44 years old and married. Maria has two kids, and both are in school. She has been running a grocery store for six years. It all started because she didn't have a job and needed to feed her family. Maria believes that with a loan, her business can get a little further ahead; she wants to have all the resources necessary for investing in her store. Maria decided to seek out a loan with the Leon Foundation 2000 (and its affiliated organizations), which will help her purchase products such as candy, soda, bread and juice. She hopes to offer better service, which will improve and increase her customer base.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Yawovi Mawulom

texts.fr: Monsieur  M. Yawovi Mawulom est un jeune homme âgé de 31 ans qui a pour activité la vente des produits pharmaceutiques dans le quartier d’Agoè. Il a commencé cette activité depuis 2007 et son objectif est de venir en aide aux personnes qui habitent dans son quartier. En 2007 il avait obtenu le premier crédit auprès de WAGES et a bien remboursé. Actuellement son stock est à moitié vide et il sollicite ce second crédit pour faire l’achat d’un lot de médicament dans la ville d’Accra la capitale du GHANA.
texts.en:
Mr. M. Yawovi Mawulom is a young man of 31 whose business is the sale of pharmaceutical products in the Agoè neighborhood. He got into this business in 2007 and his goal is to come to the aid of the people who live in his neighborhood. In 2007, he got his first loan from WAGES and paid it back appropriately. Presently, his inventory is half gone and he is asking for a second loan to buy a shipment of medicines from the town of Accra, the capital of Ghana.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of pharmaceutical products for resale

loans.name: Farahnaz Group

texts.en:
Farahnaz is the group lender of Farahnaz group. There are four members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan for expanding her business and they want to request a total loan of 56,000 Afghani.

Farahnaz wants to take a loan for her business of carpet weaving and Semen Gul also wants to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving.

Anesa wants take a loan for the business of carpet weaving and Nafesa Gul also wants to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving.

They are very thankful to AFS and to Kiva lenders who are able to support all the people in an around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand their carpet-weaving businesses

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr:
K. Victorine est née  en 1942 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN dans le Département de l'Ouémé. Victorine est mariée et mère mais tous ses enfants sont déjà majeurs donc ne sont plus à sa charge ni à la charge de leur père. Victorine a été à l’école jusqu’en classe CM2 c’est-à-dire le cours primaire. Ensuite, Victorine a appris la couture qu’elle a exercée pendant quelques années. 

Parallèlement à la couture, Victorine vendait des  divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) qui ont  pris finalement le pas sur la couture. Victorine a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits de ALIDé et elle a bien remboursé ces crédits. Victorine a besoin de moyens  financiers pour diversifier son activité avec la vente de produits de brasserie et des jus de fruit. Victorine sollicite donc un cinquième prêt de ALIDé pour l'achat d'un réfrigérateur.
texts.en:
K. Victorine was born in 1942 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin, in Ouémé county. She is married and a mother, though all her children are already of age and so are no longer in her care nor in their father’s care. Victorine has been to school through the 5th grade, that is, through primary school. Then, she learned how to sew, something she has been working at for a few years. Along with sewing, Victorine has been selling various items: candies, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardine, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, batteries, candles, etc., and this business has in the end supplanted her sewing. She has already benefited from four loans with Alidé and has repaid them. She needs funding to diversify her business by selling pub products and fruit juices. She is therefore requesting a fifth loan from Alidé to buy a refrigerator.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a charcoal vendor. He is 28 years old, single and lives in Barangay Sinili, Santiago City. He wants to have additional capital that he can use to buy more sacks of charcoal.  With this, he decided to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 5,000.00.  He is hoping that through his business, he can have an increase in income so he can continue to support his family with their needs.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nieva

texts.en:
Nieva V. is 38, married with 7 school-age children, and a resident of Cabacungan in the town of La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She raises pigs to supplement her husband's income and to make life a little bit more comfortable for their family.

She joined NWTF- Project Dungganon in 1991 but stopped in 1999. She rejoined in July of 2006, so that she could get a loan to raise pigs to augment their family income. She buys the piglets, feeds and fattens them for several months and then sells them. This adds PHP 4,000 ($83) to her family's monthly income.

The income she earns from raising pigs in her backyard for the last 3 years has helped her family a lot especially with 7 children still going to school. This is why Nieva is committed to continue and expand with this activity so that she could increase her income potential.

The PHP 18,000 she is borrowing will allow her to buy more piglets and feed than her previous loan which she ably paid off because of the weekly easy-payment scheme.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: the purchase of more piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: sale of cereals

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios C., age 54, is a multi-tasked businesswoman, as are most Filipina entrepreneurs. She has been a widow for years and currently lives with her six adult children.

Remedios owns a general store which has been around for 35 years. She also prepares barbecue and sells it to customers. Remedios makes rags from textile trimmings and sells them to customers. She also finds time to sell cosmetics and apparel through the direct-selling scheme.  From these activities, she could realize a monthly income of $980.  

She joined the Kiva field partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, in 2006.  Her previous loans with the co-op were used to purchase textile trimmings from garment factories.  She used some of the money to buy more items for her store, such as soft drinks.  Now on her tenth loan cycle, Remedios is applying for a new loan amounting to P45,000.00 which she will spread out through all her business activities.

Remedios would like to see her general store someday grow as big as a commercial grocery chain, so she could help a lot of people by providing quality products at a cheaper price.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: Additional capital for business expansion

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa is 44 years old and married with four children. She sells foodstuffs and groceries. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She requests a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Enid's Group

texts.en:
M. Enid is a 26-year-old female who is married with one child aged 6 years. She also takes care of two siblings. All the children are in school.

Enid is a hairdresser in Namasuba as well as keeping poultry at her home for two years and, so far, she is able to make 40,000/= as profits each week. She has good customer care skills and this has won her more customers, hence more profits and income. She hopes to expand her salon so that it becomes the best in Namasuba and then open other branches in future plus have an educated family.

Enid needs a loan to help increase her salon stock by buying more braids, weaves, chemicals and other cosmetics for her salon so that she can make more income.

loans.use: To increase her salon stock

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic and her husband Fredie have been married for eight years. They have two children: Jomar, 17 years old, who stopped his schooling because of financial constraints, and Jerome, 10 years of age, a grade IV student at Villa Concepcion Elementary School. Her family lives at Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. 

She operates a general store in their village. Her daily net income is PHP 500. The couple's other sources of income are gasoline retailing, and corn farming. According to Marivic, they really work hard for the education of their children. They hope that Jomar will able to attend school again. In connection with that, Marivic applied for a loan from ASKI of PHP 6,000 for her to purchase more commodities for her business. She hopes that KIVA will grant her requested loan so she can earn more income.

loans.use: Addtional capital for her retail store

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji L. is currently in the business of selling beer at a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Keji is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more fridges and extend the floor of her bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stocking more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Thea

texts.en: Mrs. Thea P. is a villager in Ta Sman village in Takeo province. She is 30-years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are in school. She and her husband, Mr. Den Sa Em, are farmers who own a 1-hectar field of land where they cultivate rice. Although this couple tries to work hard, they do not earn enough income to support their family. Mrs. Thea P. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding and fertilizers to support the rice field. This will help them increase their income and make their labor more productive.

loans.use: To purchase a breeding cow and fertilizers

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda C. is from the village of Mallig. She is 59 years old. Erlinda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda raises pigs for sale. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase pig feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is 28 years old and has a motorbike taxi business which he began two years ago. With this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, he hopes to purchase one more motorbike. It is very important to him that he be known as a reliable driver, and he describes himself as reserved but very focused. He is married and has two children who are both attending school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es: Andrea B. y su esposo se dedican desde hace 14 años a la venta de comida casera y carnitas aun muy bajo precio este negocio es llamado “Carnitas Juan”, esta pareja viven solos ya que sus hijos son grandesy se mantienen solos. Por el momento necesita el crédito para comprar mercancía para el negocio para estar preparados y no les haga falta nada para seguir trabajando en el puesto.
texts.en:
For 14 years Andrea B. and her husband have sold home-cooked food and meat, although at a very low price. The business is called 'Carnitas Juan'. The couple lives alone now that their children are grown up and look after themselves. They require a loan to buy products for the business so that they are prepared and don't lack anything to continue working at their stall.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for their business

loans.name: Arely Vanessa

texts.es:
La  señora Arely Vanessa M. R., labora como colectora de ruta en el mercado de Mayoreo de Managua, ha trabajado con Ceprodel durante cuatro años y en ese lapso ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su vivida con los  créditos que ha trabajado con Ceprodel.

El crédito solicitado es para la reparación de su carro ya que actualmente lo tiene en mal estado.

Arely dijo que gracias a los prestamos otorgados por ceprodel ha podido salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Arely Vanessa M. R. earns her living as a route collector at Managua’s wholesale market. She has worked with Ceprodel for four years and in that time she has been able to make improvements in her life thanks to the loans she has received from Ceprodel. The loan will be used to fix her car as it is not in good condition. Arely states that she has been able to get ahead thanks to the loans she has received from Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make repairs to her car.

loans.name: Jose Sergio

texts.es:
El Sr. JOSE vive en la zona norte de nuestra ciudad en la calle Calama, vive en la casa de su suegra quien no vive en el  país, vive en compañía de su esposa quien es ama de casa, no tienen hijos dependientes, el Señor Jose trabaja 12 horas al día y tiene en sus planes llegar a comprar otro vehiculo mas adelante.Existe una relacion muy bonita entre El Sr. Jose y su esposa ya que siempre estan juntos, siempre coordinan la hora del almuerzo para ir a comer juntos en un restaurant donde están pensionados, a medida de sus posibilidades ellos tratan de comprar algún tipo de bien para su hogar, como por ejemplo actualizan su computadora, compran un microondas, invierten en algún mueble para el hogar o algunas cosas por el estilo, esperemos que sigan mostrando la resposabilidad que muestran en sus pagos. Uno de sus deseos es poder tener una casa propia.

El Sr. Jose esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito
texts.en:
JOSE lvies in the northern part of our city on Calama street. He lives in his mother-in-law's house; she does not live in the country. He lives with his wife, who is a housewife; they have no dependent children. José works a twelve hour day and plans to buy a second vehicle later on. There is a very beautiful relationship between José and his wife; they are always together, they coordinate their schedules so that they can have lunch together at a restaurant where they board. As their means allow, they purchase some asset for their home. For example: they updated their computer, bought a microwave oven, invested in a piece of furniture or some such thing. We hope they will continue to show the responsibility they have so far with respect to repayments. One of their wishes is to have their own home. José is very grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shock absorbers.

loans.name: Rosie's Group

texts.en:
Rosie P. is 35 years old and she is from the town of Gomez, San Isidro. She is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosie P..

Rosie is married and has 6 school-aged children. She owns and operates a business venture providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Rosie has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from this activity.

In 2009, Rosie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Rosie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda T., 58, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Amado T., an artist, they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been doing direct selling of cosmetics and clothing of the popular brands for quite some time now.

Esmeralda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow three times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying advance orders on her cosmetics and clothing direct selling lines.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and that she will have more patrons who will continue to be loyal to her and her business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for cosmetics and clothing

loans.name: Marchie

texts.en:
Marchie J. is from the village of P-3 Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old. Marchie is single. To make a living, Marchie operates a family member's business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marchie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marchie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. This is the first loan of Marchie from GDMPC. Marchie is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marchie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a trader. She sells groceries, drinks and food items to make life meaningful for her and her family in Lagos. She has been in the business for some years and she likes the business because it gives her the opportunity to interact with her customers. 

Florence's business plan is to buy her goods in a large quantities so that she can sell in wholesale and increase her profit. She hopes for loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries, drinks and food to sell.

She is married and has 5 children: three males and 2 females. She is 44 years old and her husband is a civil servant. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, drinks and food to sell.

loans.name: Maria Matilde

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenece al banco comunal “CRISTO MORENO”; Nuestra socia vive en la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. MATILDE, ella tiene 35 años de edad es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos de 12 y 8  de edad, nuestra socia se dedica a la administración de sus propia discoteca ella tiene una discoteca en la av. La cultura llamada la choza, ella trabaja directamente en su negocio para ver la productividad y la calidad del servicio, Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para incrementar su capital de trabajo.

La socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Matilde is a member of the communal lending group “Cristo Moreno”, and lives in Cusco. She is 35, married and has two children aged 12 and 8 years. Matilde manages her own discoteque, called "La Choza" which is located on La Cultura Avenue. By working directly to grow her business in productivity and services, she seeks a loan to increase her operating capital. Mrs. Matilde is grateful for the support offered through micro-lending and is committed to paying the loan off according to the established terms and timeframe.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Cassetta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: loan to increase operating capital

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.es:
Lorenza es socia del Banco Comunal Arrieros.
Lorenza es conviviente, tiene 42 años y 5 hijos, Lorenza viaja a las diferentes ferias de la region 4 veces por semana, en donde vende ropa, además Lorenza se dedica a la compra y venta de animales.
Lorenza necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de faldas, pantalones.
Lorenza sueña con que sus hijos culminen sus estudios y salir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Lorenza is a member of the communal bank Arrieros. She is 42, lives with her partner and has 5 children. Lorenza travels to different regional markets 4 times a week, where she sells clothes. She also buys and sells animals. Lorenza requires a loan of 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of skirts and pants. Lorenza dreams about the day her children finish their studies, and in improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase skirts and pants

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth G. is from the village of Brgy.San Nicolas,Bayombong,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old. Elizabeth is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Antonio Marciano

texts.es: El Sr. Antonio Marciano Y. C. de 42 años de edad vive con su esposa y su hijo. Tiene casa propia, la cual se encuentra ubicada en la Venta Alta distrito de Santiago. Trabaja como obrero de campo en el fundo San Fernando S.A. Su esposa tambien es obrera de campo. El Sr. Antonio es una persona muy emprendedora, que gracías a su empeño y dedicación a logrado salir adelante y poder construir parte de su vivienda. El Sr Antonio requiere el crédito para poder terminar de construir su casa. Su sueño, según nos comenta es terminar de construir dicha vivienda, para poder tener una mejor calidad de vida. El Sr. Antonio esta muy agradecido por el apoyo que le podamos brindar a través de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Mr. Antonio Marciano Y. C. is 42 years old, and he lives with his wife and their son. He is the owner of his house, located in La Venta Alta, in the Santiago district. He works as a farm labourer in the San Fernando S.A. estate, and his wife is a farm labourer as well. Antonio is a very enterprising person who, thanks to his commitment and dedication has succeeded in getting by and in building part of his house. Antonio is requesting a loan in order to finish building his house. He told us that his dream is to finish constructions on his house to reach a better quality of life. Antonio is really thankful for the help we can offer through this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finish building his house.

loans.name: Favor Group

texts.en:
Rachel C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Favor. She is 33 years old, is married, and has seven children who range from 4 to 16 years old. She also cares for one sibling. Rachel was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to lack of financial support.

For 14 years, Rachel has been selling frozen meat, such as chicken and pork, in West Point community, Monrovia, Liberia.

Rachel plans to use her 11,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 55,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more frozen chicken and pork to sell. She describes herself as moderate.

Rachel’s goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more frozen chicken and pork to sell

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria B. is from the village of Bangko, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Candelaria owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily use products such as sardines, milo, cocoa, biscuits, shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Candelaria has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Candelaria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to provide additional capital for her business. Candelaria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Candelaria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai S. is 45 years old, married, and devoted to her child, who is already married and lives at home. She is married to 50-year-old Chounvinh, who helps support the family by working in the construction field. Mai S. owns a small business selling fruit to villagers as a means of income.
The family is often affected by transport problems as it has no vehicle. Therefore, Mai S. has decided to seek a loan of $600 USD in order to purchase a used motorcycle to provide transport for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle to provide family transport

loans.name: Olga Cristina

texts.es:
Olga de 59 años, ella tiene un local de venta de pescados, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil, tiene dos hijos ya mayores de edad que le ayudan en el negocio. 

Ella empezó vendiendo encebollados (plato típico del Ecuador, llena pescados, cebolla) en una carreta recorriendo las calles de las Orquídeas, poco a poco con esfuerzo pudo alquilar un local para su negocio. Ahora ella trabaja vendiendo encebollados desde las 07h00am hasta las 18h00pm todos los días. 

Ella quiere comprar con el préstamo pescados y cebollas para hacer mas encebollado en su negocio, en el futuro quiere tener otro local  y tener empleados fijos.
texts.en:
Olga, 59, sells fish. She lives in Las Orquídeas, Guayaquil. She has two adult children that help her with the business. She started out selling “encebollados” from a cart along Orquídeas’s streets. (The base of this seafood soup is called “sofrito” and is a pungent mix of tomatoes, onions, cumin, chili and cilantro. The protein element and foundation for the stock is tuna. The starch element is yuca a starchy root vegetable that requires time to cook down the coarse threads found within its stalk. The result is a delicious aromatic savory and spicy soup that is traditionally topped with pickled onions and tomatoes.) Gradually, with much effort, she was able to rent a locale for her business. She is now open for business selling encebollados from 7am until 6pm every day. She wants to use the loan to buy fish and onions to make more encebollados and in the future would like to have a second locale and to have permanent employees.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and onions.

loans.name: Trabajando Para El Futuro 2 & 9 Group

texts.en:
Eladia is the coordinator of her group Trabajando para el Futuro 2 & 9. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and 3 children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to have her own house built with concrete blocks. In the meantime she plans to continue to enjoy her current home.

Eladia is excited to be taking her 10th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She has had her business for more than 6 years after she started selling at home, while her husband was fishing. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying all kinds of seafood (octopus, fish, squid, etc). She will use the profits from her business to buy school supplies. She also needs to buy a dining table and and a vehicle to transport the merchandise.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she needed the loans for her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy seafood

loans.name: Samuel Mwangi

texts.en:
Samuel Mwangi K. is 42 years old, married to Priscah Wanjiku and has four children who attend school.

Samuel started commercial farming last year. He was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to plow his farm, buy maize seedlings and plant them.

Samuel is hoping to expand his farm and also to open a grocery shop in the future.

loans.use: To plow his farm and buy maize seedlings

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Mrs. Oyun D. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Oyun and her husband, Lkhasuren, have been running a furniture-making business since 1998. They have managed to send the elder daughter to Korea to study. Their son is a sculpture who works on a freelance basis and also helps with the parents’ business. The younger daughter studies at the local University of Agriculture.

Oyun and her husband buy materials such as plywood, HDF board, glue and fabric from local wholesalers and make different household furniture for apartments and gers (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). They sell them at Narantuul and Denjiin myanga, the two biggest outdoor markets in Ulaanbaatar.

Since Oyun and her husband started their business, they managed to buy a family house with a plot of land. Currently they are doing some renovation to the house. The loan they are requesting will be used to renovate the house and to increase their working capital and inventory.

loans.use: To renovate their house and increase their working capital and inventory

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S., 42, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia: an area known for palm products. S. sells groceries, earning an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of about 3 per day. The family has to spend USD 44 on food, USD 8 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. 

S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. is not available.

loans.use: to buy more groceries and goods to sell

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a very supportive lady. She is involved in an embroidery business. She does this work to support her family financially. She comes from a mid-sized city, Kasur, which is known in Pakistan for its leather industry. She owns a 2-room brick house in an area named Basti Shahdra and has been living in it with her family for over 20 years. She is married to G. N. who works in a factory for a meager income. 

Razia has given birth to two daughters. Her elder daughter has completed her 10th class and now she helps Razia in completing her embroidery orders. Her younger daughter is 8 years of age and studies in a local school. 

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery items such as clothes, beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk quantity to fill larger orders on time. This loan investment will help her in making more money and to improve the financial condition of her family. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes it will have a positive impact on her business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Razia.

loans.use: To buy embroidery items for embroidery business

loans.name: Inocencio

texts.en:
Inocencio Z. is from the village of Brgy. Cutar, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 26 years old and single. To make a living, Inocencio owns and operates a business raising livestock. His main source of income comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Inocencio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Inocencio joined ASKI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase breeding livestock. Inocencio is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Inocencio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jorge Ruben

texts.es:
El señor  Jorge Ruben J. S. tiene 42 años de edad y vive en una casa de propia vivienda que esta ubicada en la comunidad de Santa Ana de la ciudad de Tarija. Jorge es casado con la señora Marina Janeth Altamirano Sandoval con quien tiene 2 hijos.  Jorge se dedica al servicio de profesor del area rural y en sus horas libres se dedica al transporte libre de pasajeros como taxista ambas actividades las viene desarrollando desde hace mas de 20 años.  El cuenta con extensiones de terreno donde tiene ganado y además siembra papa.

Francisco necesita  comprar semillas de papa para sembrar, de esa forma mejorar sus ingresos para brindarles una mejor vida a su esposa e hijos, es por eso que el crédito será destinado para la compra de dichas semillas.
                                                                                                                                                                                                       
Jorge nos cuenta que quiere darle a su esposa e hijos toda la comodidad que pueda, por eso nos dice que el proximo credito que solicite sera para mejorar las condiciones de su casa donde vive.
texts.en:
Mr. Jorge Ruben J. S. is 42 years old. He lives in a house that he owns in the Santa Ana community in the city of Tarija. Jorge is married to Mrs. Marina Janeth Altamirano. They have 2 children. Jorge works as a rural area teacher. In his off hours he works as an independent taxi driver transporting passengers. He has been carrying out both of these activities for more than 20 years. He owns plots of land where he has cattle and also plants potatoes.

Jorge needs to buy potato seeds for planting. This way he will improve his income to offer a better life for his wife and children. This is why the loan will go towards purchasing these seeds.
                                                                                                                                                                                                       
Jorge tells us that he wants to provide his wife and children with every comfort that he can. For this reason he informs us that the next loan he requests will be for improving the condition of the house where he lives.

loans.use: Purchase of potato seed for planting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy ingredients for making her tortillas

loans.name: Nuraly

texts.en:
Nuraly U. is 30 years old and married with three sons. He was born in the Batken region, in the south of Kyrgyzstan in a farm-worker’s family. From early childhood, he helped his parents in farming. After finishing school, he started to engage in land cultivating, but it was not very profitable because of the deficiency of cropland. 

In 2002, in order to find better place to live, Nuraly decided to move to the Chui region in the north of the country. Gaining a wide experience in raising livestock, Nuraly started his business in cattle breeding, which became the main source of income for his family. With initial capital of 10,000 Kyrgyzstan soms (KGS), he managed to earn about 12,000 KGS monthly.  Due to his strong efforts, Nuraly has established his farm and today it has two bull calves and still needs to be developed.  

Nuraly plans to use the loan of 80,000 KGS to broaden his business through buying three bull calves. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle.

Nuraly is doing his best to provide good conditions for his children. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Francis Janethe

texts.es:
La señora Francis Janethe P. Zúniga es una mujer trabajadora, esforzada y emprendedora quien vende ropa interior, cosméticos desde hace diez años  y hace dos año inicio con  un pequeño kiosco en un colegio.  Ella tiene siete años de trabajar con Adim en los cuales su negocios han ido creciendo y desarrollando.

P. de 37 años madre de tres hijos de 22, 14 y 10 años invertirá el crédito en ropa interios (blúmer, hilos, bikinis, brasier, fajas etc. y en productos para el kiosko ya que se acerca el regreso a clases.
texts.en:
Francis Janethe P. Zúniga is a hardworking woman, motivated and entrepreneurial. She has been selling undergarments and cosmetics for 10 years. Two years ago she opend up a small stand at a school. She has been working with Kiva partner Adim for sevenn years, during which time her businesses have been growing and developing.

She is 37 years old and the mother of three children, who are 22, 14, and 10 years old. She will invest this loan in undergarments (bloomers, thongs, bikinis, bras, girdles, etc.) as well as in merchandise for the stand since it is nearing the time when school will be back in session.

loans.use: Clothes and merchandise for the stand
